fields.headline: Portsmouth aim to add Brazilian blend with in-demand Denilson
fields.bodyText: Portsmouth are giving a trial to Denilson, once the world's most expensive player but now a free agent at 28 having been released by Bordeaux in the summer, although the Saudi Arabian side Al-Nasr claim to have an agreement to sign him. Denilson, capped 61 times by Brazil and a member of the 1998 and 2002 World Cup squads, joined Real Betis for a then world- record £22m from Sao Paulo in 1998 and moved on to the French club for an undisclosed fee in 2005. Fernando Torres has extended his Atletico Madrid contract until 2009. "It is an important day for the club and it's fans because Torres is more than just another player," a spokesman said. "He was developed through our youth system and for some time has been the reference for the club on and off the pitch. He is an example for all the youth players who dream of playing in the Vicente Calderon one day." Torres, 22, joined Atletico at 11, scored his first goal for the senior team in May 2001 and has been their leading scorer in each of the past four seasons. England have equalled their all-time high of fourth place in the Fifa rankings and moved above Italy, whose form since winning the World Cup two months ago sees them slip to fifth. Scotland are up six places to No34, Northern Ireland have risen 14 to No58 after the shock win over Spain and overtook Wales, who slip six places to No62. The Republic of Ireland are down five and share 43rd with Iran. David Johnson of Nottingham Forest has retired due to a back injury. The 30-year-old has been absent since the end of 2005 and surgery to cure a disc problem proved to be unsuccessful. The striker cost £3.5m in 2001 when he arrived from Ipswich and also counts Manchester United and Bury as former clubs. Ferenc Puskas, the former Hungary, Honved and Real Madrid forward who managed Panathinaikos to the 1971 European Cup final, has been admitted to an intensive care unit in Budapest. The 79-year-old, who suffers from Alzheimer's disease, is was moved from a hospital room, where he is a long-term patient. Puskas scored 83 goals in 84 matches for his country and helped them reach the 1954 World Cup final, the Battle of Berne, as well as winning three European Cups with the Spanish club.
